pros: Boise state has a great work environment and almost everybody I met had the same positive, Bronco spirit. The campus is growing and continually adding new buildings and opportunities for students and staff.

pros: Lots of freedom to work independently. Great opportunities to meet people and share ideas.
cons: Pay is reliant on grants much of the time. You can love what you are doing but if you can't get a grant to keep doing it, it can be difficult to stay on.

pros: The people that surround the community of Boise State are amazing. Those people really make you fall in love with the city and the institution
cons: It is very expensive to live in Boise and wages are not matching

pros: In addition to standard health and retirement benefits, the tuition waiver for full-time employees is amazing. Its very exciting to be contributing to an amazing cause and you will have opportunities to work on projects that have a significant impact on the community. Beautiful campus Next to impossible to get fired after your six month probation period if you are an hourly employee. Good opportunity for someone looking to "soft quit"
cons: Inept middle management Toxic working culture Outdated compensation policies. The cost of living in Boise has skyrocketed over the last 2 years, with minimal increase in compensation. I have multiple positions open for longer than a year and am unable to get applicants because the pay is around 60% for similar positions in the area. Little accountability for staff after the 6-month probationary period. I had employees using drugs and getting violent in the workplace and was unable to fire them. Convoluted procurement processes Constant battles between employees require intervention from the State of Idaho Department of Human Resources as well as the Boise State University Human Resources department. Inconsistent standards for employees The majority of employees have never had a job outside of school, or lived away from their parent's home. This gives them unrealistic expectations and more pride than experience. Zero respect for my initial job title. I accepted temporary responsibilities when my first supervisor left. Sixt months after the new supervisor started and a year after my temporary merit increase, I was denied a request to return to my original duties and job description. Despite clear documentation of events, I was bullied and threatened into assuming the responsibilities of a director with a fraction of the pay. Honestly would consider suing the organization if I wasn't dependent of the Tuition waiver.

pros: Great upper management, supportive professors.
cons: Some professors overwork students in their labs.

pros: Can't beat summers off, and it's amazing to be around youthful energetic creative and hard working students, they drove me to become better than I ever thought I could be.

pros: - Some of the most passionate and dedicated colleagues - Great benefits
cons: The university is horribly run. There is no organization or clear communication university-wide, just band-aid solutions for long-term problems. Management does not take the time to try and solve the root causes, nor do they put the effort in being efficient and productive with its resources. Instead, they create a lot of busy work for understaffed and overworked employees. The pay is abysmal, on top of added expenses for basic utilities because the organization fails to provide for them for the staff (parking, coffee, etc). Everyone is expected to be a Swiss Army knife worker on the pay that is 20% below market average minimum. The priority is a lot less about accomplishing work that is sustainable and relevant, and a lot more about creating busy work and having non-stop meetings about the busy work. The lack of transparency, organization, and open communication puts the stress on everyone trying to actually contribute to the organization. There is no training or unified standard within the university, so there is a lot of connect-the-dots, wild goose chasing, and scheduling the same meetings over and over to understand the basic knowledge and context to even start setting yourself up for success. Even after some years of work and gaining experience, the work you do will still remain to be an advanced version of busy work - anything challenging and growth-fostering gets outsourced to vendors and third parties, thus, taking away actual career development opportunities within the organization.

pros:
I worked on campus as an administrative assistant for a government agency that is housed on campus, so I reported both to the government agency and to the university.

Good things about the job: 
-They were flexible and understanding about my class schedule and worked with me so I could attend school while working full time.
-Compensation and benefits were good, especially discounted tuition. Considering my youth, they were not stingy with my starting salary and raises.
-Easy hiring process
-Low stress. I had a lot of down time on the job and my primary responsibility was to help callers and walk ins. If I wasn't busy with that and didn't have any pending projects or tasks, I was welcome to read, study, or surf the web. No need to appear busy if I wasn't.
-I never got calls on my days off or had to work late- they respected my life outside of work well.
-Nice environment to be on campus near students and campus activities
-Good training, I knew what was expected of me at work and was trained well on how to do it. If I had questions my supervisor was easily accessible to help me out.
cons:
-The team I worked with were polite but distant. I only had 1 really good friend at work, and one decently good friend. The leadership was a bit aloof.
-You have to pay for a parking pass, which is a few hundred dollars depending on how close to your office you want to be. I feel like that should be free for staff, or at least discounted or have a designated lot.
-Some bureaucracy that comes with an organization of that size: work orders, IT tickets can be slow to be resolved. Sometimes there's a lot of layers to work through to get approval for simple things.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boise, ID
pros: Good city to live. Not super pricey. Good overall work-life balance. Some impactful research is being done and the engineering department is working towards becoming better ranked and attract more talent.
cons: Very conservative state. Not many opportunities coming from career fairs or alumni network. Career fairs are almost exclusively with companies hiring in Idaho, which is limiting in terms of opportunities. I love the place but the school is no MIT so getting jobs in big tech or academia with a degree from here might be (will definitely be) a bit more challenging- It’ll depend a lot on who your advisor knows and connects you to during your graduate program. Most people I know who got postdoc positions in national labs or engineering jobs after graduation heavily relied upon connections they made during grad school through their advisors. The school is heavily dependent on one or two big partnerships, which clearly influences its research and direction.

pros: Good position with a flexing schedule
cons: Nothing much happen to me

pros: Excellent online MBA program. I recommend it.
cons: It is online so you do not get the in person experience but they do a good job of substituting with continuous interaction.

pros: Everyday is something new and different in the event world, amazing team environment, fast-paced, meeting new people everyday, do not have to sit at a desk all day
cons: Some late nights depending on event

pros: Great University to do your Master's
cons: The program is stressful in general

pros: Great Community and a university on the up
cons: Crippled by an inefficient bureaucracy and leadership that doesn't reform

job_title: Student Customer Service Representative in Boise, ID
pros: Very flexible with student hours
cons: Expected to do as much work as a full time salaried employee with benefits, but only paid a low hourly wage.

pros: If you enjoy teaching, this is good experience
cons: Lacked departmental support, supplies, best practices

job_title: Undergraduate Learning Assistant in Boise, ID
pros: I enjoyed tutoring for the professor that I worked with
cons: No cons associated with tutoring

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boise, ID
pros: Good supervisor, Got lots of 5G equipment to complete the experiment
cons: needs more 5G wireless course

pros: There is flexibility in scheduling, part of a community
cons: Low pay, cap you at how many hours you can work

review_title: Good benefits, relaxed environment, low pay
pros: Good benefits and relaxed environment
cons: Low pay, as expected for state employment

pros: Health insurance is amazing ; fu.n Working with youth
cons: Disorganized, inefficient, typical civil service despondent attitudes by people beaten down by the system. Sad, because it’s a cool school with awesome students.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boise, ID
pros: good facilities and good colleagues
cons: I did not find any cons

pros: Loved working here and loved the students.
cons: State legislature can be difficult to work with, esp. regarding education budget.

pros: Flexible for students, accommodating, friendly
cons: lower wage, less room for growth

review_title: Decent Engineering School for Graduate Students
pros: Funding availability, helpful faculty members, excellent location
cons: Too few research areas, crowded office space for grad students

pros: Good enviroment for working, nice prople
cons: Not that well paid for all the job made

job_title: Distribution Center Manager in Boise, ID
pros: Great community to be a part of
cons: Can't think of any real cons

review_title: Great place and team to work with!
pros: Strong leadership, friendly staff and flexible schedule
cons: Learning and finding work-arounds in the PeopleSoft System

pros: Up and coming research university. Many highly intelligent and helpful PI and staff.
cons: Does not have some of the more advanced equipment that you might expect from a larger research university.

pros: Great place to work as well as great people.
cons: No parking which has always been an issue.9

pros: Flexible hours and understanding mentor
cons: Difficult work and indefinite solutions

pros: Best campus life and great experience
cons: not the best professors and the city is dull

pros: Flexible schedule, wonderful team and management, good way to get involved with the school
cons: Pay is low and can only work up to 15 hours

pros:
- Easy going environment
- Great benefits
cons:
- Low pay
- Can have non-traditional hours

pros: Great campus environment and awesome co-workers
cons: It's gets cold in Boise!

pros: You learn about many important offices at Boise State and get to participate in fun events.
cons: Some early mornings and not the most competitive pay.

pros: Nice working people in the department
cons: Department is most focused on Cybersecurity

review_title: Best vape team in the country!
pros: Lots of grater vapers on this team!
cons: Sometimes expectations are too high.

pros: Best faculty with great knowledge
cons: Daycare for kids not readily available, it has a long waiting list

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boise, ID
pros: International student friendly, Nice Environment
cons: no strong PHD student alumni group

pros: Great benefits and professional development
cons: Lack of competitive pay and stucture

review_title: BSU_ A Great Place to work
pros: A great work environment in Higher Education.
cons: None to speak of we love our students.

pros: BSU has good camaraderie and benefits
cons: Salary not as competitive as private sector

job_title: Graduate Electronic Engineer in Los Angeles, CA
pros: I fell very comfortable at BSU
cons: There are a lot of proficient staff in BSU

pros: -flexible schedule to work with students classes
cons: -not a super creative environment

pros: Flexible schedule Close proximity Social networking
cons: Low wage Variety Boring at times

review_title: Worked at Boise State University for three years in the "Financial Aid Office"
job_title: Customer Service Representative II in Boise, ID
pros: The employees and students were wonderful to work with.  Very friendly environment.  I loved my job working with the students.  My job was always challenging with all the changes in federal regulations but loved it.  Going home knowing that you helped a student and or family make a life changing decision for the good was worth every penny.   Good benefits!  Great University!  Love the Boise State Broncos!
cons: Full of politics.  As for leadership, senior counselor needs to go.  Lies & deception.  Ruined my retirement and a job I loved.  Human Resource office is of no help to the employees.

review_title: Boise State University, improving, but not quite there...
pros: Generally a good working atmosphere, generally a low stress environment, good location, and job security is pretty strong there as you would imagine.
cons: No training, no unified interdepartmental processes, salaries for staff are very low. BSU was subject to an IRS audit and although they have been aggressive in ensuring compliance with the IRS, their implementation is not always well thought out, nor are new policies distributed to faculty/staff.

review_title: Boise State is like most universities.  They are elitists.
pros: They take care of their own, as long as their own meet their standard as an elitist.  They are generally good to their students.
cons: You can be a great professor, really know your stuff and present it well, but if you don't fit their mold you can be left in the dumpster.  They don't treat their students this way, just other faculty.  The only standard they really hold their professors to is a high amount of publishing.  Their teaching abilities are not examined or improved upon if lacking.

job_title: Fill Time Staff in Boise, ID
pros: Freedom to try things and pretty much do whatever you want, and get paid, with benefits.
cons: No accountability across the university leads to a lack of good management. Culture suffers, and it feels frustrating and bleak knowing nothing really matters. New initiatives are unplanned and feel random, and almost pointless. There's no clear, singular direction for everyone to get behind. The university wastes thousands of hours of employee time on short-lived, and poorly planned/executed pursuits. The result is the loss of good talent when employees give up and move on to better places. When this happens, managers assume it was a failure of the employee, instead of looking at their own failure to drive organizational change.

job_title: Senior Grant Accountant in Boise, ID
pros: Beautiful campus, competitive wages when you come with a valued skill set, and wonderful co workers
cons: Contract only.  You never know year to year, if your contract will be renewed, and there is a lot of reorganization happening on this campus. Entire departments can be laid off, or merged with others, and you only get 3 months notice that you are going to be without a job when this happens.

pros: Depending on the area you work in, and for whom, there is a lot of flexibility. Dependent on your supervisor, you are able to focus on outside interests as long as the job gets done. The tuition waiver is hands down the best benefit. There is a lot of bureaucracy, but it is a state agency, it is what it is.
cons: Salary is hands down the worst part of working for the State, and Boise State is no different. It is challenging to keep good talent, when the private sector will pay double for the same work. Because it is an educational institution, some areas require degrees for work that really does not require a degree to do.

pros: Tuition waiver, benefits, flexible schedule. Full time university employees are eligible for 9 credits at $5/ credit, the job comes with the standard state benefits package; retirement, medical, dental. The flexible schedule is manager dependent.
cons: Pay, advancement. Idaho wages are strongly depressed and BSU is low even for Idaho. They will continually took for reasons to pay you less either on hiring or through cutting department funds. I have also noticed that in general BSU would rather hire a new person than give an existing employee a shot at moving up.

pros: Growth in the metro area and expanding industry collaborations make Boise State and Boise in general an excellent place to develop professionally.  In the administrative ranks, it is possible to create your own career path rather than having it laid out for you.
cons: Resistance from "long timers" makes implementing change difficult for those attempting to improve processes.  For major changes, administration seems reluctant to gather data from other like entities to inform choices for implementation, assuming that "no one else understands our needs".  The freedom to create a career path has a down side:  several key positions are held by people with questionable or insufficient qualifications.

pros: The company provides a fee waiver for college classes to yourself and your dependents.  This can provide future advancement opportunities.  Networking is essential in the university and a lot of times your employment is more of a who you know over what you know.  If they think you are the right fit they will train you on the flesh of the job.
cons: The classes offered will not always work out with your job hours and it may take quite awhile to earn that degree or certificate.

pros: They are very flexible and work around your class schedule. In the MLC I didn't really have any problems trading shifts when things come up, or getting extra shifts when I had more time. When It's not busy in the MLC you have an opportunity to work on your own homework.
cons: If you are assigned as a classroom assistant, you will not get a chance to work on your own homework during the class times like you can (when it's not busy) in the walk-in tutoring centers.

review_title: Great Place to Work and Live!
pros: Boise State is not only a great place to go to school, but a wonderful place to work. Boise State is in a great location that is hard to beat -- heart of downtown, next to the foothills, and borders the river.
cons: There are few downsides to working for Boise State University. Sometimes it can be difficult to park especially when there are events occurring, but other than that, no negative things to report!

review_title: Eclectic working environments with a few employee logistical issues.
pros: Pleasant staff and energetic environment. Exposure to many different technologies. Low cost to take classes or help children with attendance costs. The retirement package was very good.
cons: PARKING, PARKING, PARKING. To make employees pay for terrible parking conditions was very frustrating. The lack of a true break-room or employee restrooms was also frustrating. Employee rating systems for reviews seemed to be quite different from manager to manager. In my particular area, the on-boarding process was non-existent.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boise, ID
pros: Very relaxed, generally non-stressful environment. As long as it appears 'something' is being accomplished, nobody really pays attention.  Typically very nice, state of the art equipment to use for research.
cons: Too relaxed for a productive program.  Not much for oversight equates to not much being done.  Career likely suffers as a result of lack of publications and conference attendance due to a very real lack of urgency in general.

pros: Work is very flexible and is a combination of a regular schedule and grading papers when it is convenient. Pay is decent for part time work.
cons: Work is only part time and some weeks are less work then other weeks.  It would be difficult to make enough to cover all typical expenses while going to school and working just this job alone.

pros: large amount of freedom, supervisors are open to feedback
cons: large bureaucracy, students are often neglected.

job_title: Advertising Sales Manager in Boise, ID
pros: Great work environment, staff really tries to help you develop skills, easy to get around school schedule if you are a student
cons: The pay could be better I am a Manager getting $8.25 and most other departments pay $10.00. Should be consistent among all departments.

review_title: Great place for a student to work.
job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Boise, ID
pros: The pay is good for a student. The hours are extremely lenient. It is a great job for your resume. I love my job. I'm always learning and given chalenges.
cons: Have to do some tedious things in the lab. Annoying safety training is required for everyone. I feel like I always need to be there to make sure things run smoothly do it'd hard to take a vacation.

pros: Fun working with professors. Interesting seeing the behind the scenes politics from a peers point of view rather than just a student. Students always had new and unique questions. Working as a TA as an undergrad helped cement the concepts I learned when I took the course I helped teach.
cons:
Professors are always over extended. They have a tendency to dump work on you that might be outside your specific scope. I ended up helping manage the class rather than just show up for work and help the students.

Grading is terrible. Spent many long nights grading quizzes and exams.

job_title: Student IT Assistant II in Boise, ID
pros:
- Very friendly environment
- Flexible Schedule for students
cons:
- Pros/Cons really depend on the department
- Low pay
- It's hard for them to acknowledge a students potential. Although this can be understandable since it's student employees.

review_title: A fast growing metropolitan research University in a fascinating city to live!
pros: Plenty of support from peers provides ability to take risks and grow. Work is appreciated if one is motivated and driven. Nice place to live in. Cost of living is low and housing is very much affordable.
cons: The University is growing to become a regional Research University of distinction, but will take time to reach Research One status. Not always the best students you can hope for.

review_title: It was a fun learning job opportunity.
job_title: Web Development Intern in Boise, ID
pros: I worked there to gain some experience as web development Intern.
cons: They did not need a permanent employee. They just give me the opportunity to learn about the job and to gain experience.

review_title: Over loaded with work - had to work weekends to keep caught up.
pros: They always encourage an active lifestyle.  The gym on campus is a small fee for employees and is a great facility.
cons: Overwhelmed with the amount of work.  My direct supervisor was great and amazing to work with but upper management left a lot to be desired.

job_title: Customer Satisfaction Specialist in Boise, ID
pros: I was a customer service rep in the Bookstore. It was great for a college job, very flexible with hours and easy to do well in.
cons: Management was an absolute joke at the time, too wrapped up in petty stuff to be effective at all and also lacking anybody who could really lead outside of one person. Too much in the way of politics. Also paid minimum wage with infrequent evaluations (in theory every 6-8 months, but was lucky if it happened with in 14-15)

review_title: A great place to build a career
pros: Great work-life balance, great lifestyle in Boise. The university is a nimble and up and coming research university. There is substantial support for faculty research.
cons: Lack of support from state government, chronic fighting with University of Idaho over resources and prestige. Salaries are typically below market for faculty.

pros: Situated in Boise, ID, which is a nice place to live.
cons: Administrators are arrogant and pay no heed to policy. This appears to be true across various units on campus and at various levels. The institution will retaliate against whistleblowers. The institution has been on a building frenzy for about a decade and is now in a precarious financial position. This has led to faculty being encouraged to keep students moving through even if they perform marginally. Faculty and staff are grossly underpaid.

review_title: Great experience at an "up and coming" university.
pros: The people and environment have been mostly positive, open, and adaptable. They have many great areas of research and a lot of opportunity to participate in a lot of areas of research.
cons: The university isn't as well known as many universities which could make finding job opportunities more challenging later. There are still kinks in some of the newer graduate programs.

pros: Good benefits - plenty of time off and sick leave, along with good medical and 401K match.
cons:
Old-school style in many departments. Bureaucratic and slow moving in many places. Raises are the typical "cost of living" 1-2% each year. Promotions and salary increases are extremely hard to come by, even for top performers.
Management seems to be struggling with incompetent employees. People are in positions because they've been at BSU forever, not because they are good at their jobs.

review_title: Only a good place to work if you get a permanent position
pros: Nice people, excellent store manager
cons: Some department managers are bad with people, the pay is awful for students and worse for non-students --except for managerial positions

job_title: Enterprise Business Analyst in Boise, ID
pros: Professional staff get excellent vacation leave on top of holidays.  It's fun to be on a college campus.
cons: It can be very hard to move up the ladder, especially a transition from a classified position to a professional position.  Pay is generally low and it's not uncommon for people work second jobs.

pros: The facutly and staff who work at Boise State are deeply committed folks who work tirelessly to support our students.
cons: Current trends outside the university put great pressure on the organization (financially and socially). It becomes very difficult to keep up when the leadership is continually chasing the latest idea.

review_title: Favoritism, Discrimination, Harassment,.. you name it
pros: Boise is a nice city to live with four seasons.
cons:
Despite the locale of a nice emerging city, this University has serious issues with no remedial actions being taken or hope in sight. The administration is corrupt from top to the bottom, and the only game they play is to water down the standards of education in the State of Idaho by boosting enrollment. The foundational studies program is a disaster with greater than 85% students getting A grades in important courses. There is a constant pressure on instructors to pass everyone to boost enrollment so that the administration can boast of highest enrollment numbers in the state, and get largest paychecks in the state of Idaho. 
In addition to consistently falling standards of education, there are issues of rampant cronyism and discrimination against minorities. There are gangs and clubs of dominant group among faculty and administrators with blatant disregard for scholarship. Accomplished researchers, who are not aligned with a certain gang, are harassed and their incompetent counterparts promoted with several recent policy changes customized to promote incompetency. The message is clear – intellectuals and minorities, even if more competent, are not welcome here. If you are here, you are at the mercy of the monocolor administration. Deans and Chairs are picked on the basis of cronyism and in the words of senior administration, “Academic competence has nothing to do with leadership.” In other words, intellectual minorities must do all the work of upholding academic standards while the incompetent cronies of one group will be made your bosses, DIlbert style. In summary, if you are competent and talented with great ideas, this place is not for you. If you belong to the dominant group and are good at sucking up and playing the game of incompetents and “sail” with them, you will thrive in this borough. If you have seen the “Don’t Fail Idaho” advertisement, don’t think BSU will do any wonders to your future by attending it. They are doing a good job of failing Idaho by lowering the standards of education so that administrator can keep getting their fattest paychecks in the state.

review_title: Awesome flexibility working for Boise State in research
pros: Make my own hours, including how much or how little I choose to work. Work around my class schedule, so I have more work/life balance
cons: Some labs take time to get you what you need. At times, our group pays for lab time that isn't used efficiently due to the lab managers not keeping up with calibrating equipment.

pros: Tasks are straight-forward and the supervisors don't micromanage which allows for a great deal of independence as long as you know what you're doing. The pay is meager but the tuition deferment more than makes up for it.
cons: The lack of oversight can be a huge advantage or disadvantage. Although I enjoyed it, others did not. Some people like shorter reins, others prosper when given space.

review_title: The overall experience working as an assistant researcher at BSU was good.
pros: The people I worked with was the best part of working for the Department of Geosciences. Everyone was pleasant, hard-working, and eager to help each other.
cons: The only downside was having to front the gas money to get to the research site. No big deal though, it was just a matter of paperwork.

pros: It is great to be a graduate assistant at Boise State. With tuition waivers and stipends, it definitely makes it easier to get a graduate degree.
cons: Halfway through the year, the stipend was changed to hourly pay. This was frustrating, as a contract was signed for a certain stipend, which won't be met since I'm not able to get hours during holidays, etc.

review_title: A good place for a graduate student
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boise, ID
pros: Stipend covers living expenses in the area. Healthcare is included. I had no problem taking courses in different departments. The campus is centralized and very accessible.
cons: As at any university, lots of paperwork is required for everything. The graduate college makes blanket rule changes that can be good for one department, but make no sense for another.

pros: Working on campus provided good work and school balance.  Big plus was no commuting.  When working for professors they made sure your grades stead up before pushing the research as an undergraduate researcher
cons: Sometime to get everything in you had to work late nights.

review_title: A very enriching experience, that taught me a lot about myself and how to serve customers.
job_title: Guest Service Representative in Boise, ID
pros: I got to help and assist people in what they need, along with having a very flexible work schedule.
cons: The people I worked with were not the most reliable.

pros: Friendly staff, great way to make connections in the higher ed realm.
cons: Depending on the department they will work you to the bone. They love salary folks and to take away your life.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boise, ID
pros:
Good work environment, nice faculty members. Everybody was really helpful and nice. 
A lot of team work and interdisciplinary research. Good for networking and developing new skills.
cons: Some projects required working long hours, but that was just a choice to finish things on time. Insurance plan from BSU is not the best but covers the basics.

job_title: Assistant Systems Administrator in Boise, ID
pros: It's great to work where I also attend classes. It makes it easy to go from class to work. It's also nice being able to sometimes work on homework.
cons: It isn't an ideal pay rate unfortunately.

review_title: A great place to develop skills for a career
job_title: Student IT Worker in Boise, ID
pros: Flexible work schedules and excellent networking opportunities. You will know what it is like to work in the real world. There were a decent amount of resources.
cons: Not much room for growth because of budget constraints. If a student does not get hired on, they must discontinue their employment after graduation.

pros: Boise state university is a very good regional school, welcoming Bronco fan. Very dynamic, great culture. Good place to start your career and get free education.
cons: There are a lot of turn over at every level. complex structure, heavy overhead management, very low pay cause a lot of turn over.

pros: Maybe someday upper management will replace the Supervisor in maintenance.
cons: Maintenance supervisor has no skill set for any of carpentry, painting, or senior craftsman work.  Consistently creating work drama every week. Supervisor talks behind people’s back. I don’t recommend anybody to apply for any positions that are supervised by the maintenance supervisor.

review_title: everyone was treated fair but not equal.
pros: Its a small school and you will get to know everyone. The students are from everyone which leaves a very diverse community to work with.
cons: Sometimes they are scared to try something new because they are stuck in the past. New ideas are thrown to the side for more traditional ideas.

review_title: Good place to work and live
pros: Small city, relatively low living cost. The university cares about the growth of their employees. And as a teacher, they offer a lot of training opportunities to help you become a better teacher.
cons: As more people moving to boise, the living cost here is getting higher and higher, the population is also growing.

pros: Since they employ lots of students BSU is very accommodating and willing to work with varied schedules. Work is challenging and valued at every turn. Compensation is very good for part-time work.
cons: Working with the university means staying inside the university, so it's sometimes hard to network with people outside of the college.

pros: Employers want you to get the most experience and knowledge you can. They want you to go far and encourage you to learn, grow, and be promoted. They are also very flexible around your school schedule.
cons: Sometimes some not so glamorous jobs, but not bad.

review_title: Great place for students to work
pros: Great place for a student position. They work with your class schedule. You can do homework during your shift for many positions.
cons: Low pay for some of the positions. Hard to obtain a student job, especially if you don't qualify for work study.

job_title: Student Office Assistant in Boise, ID
pros: Very Flexible and gives you real world experience in the business department
cons: Some managers are better than others, but you get that in most places of employment

pros: Tuition wavier, good pay, build deep relationship with professors and staff. Exposure to research (depending on the department)
cons: not the best work-life balance. Depending on the department, your work load can vary. So project require you to burn the midnight oil.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boise, ID
pros: The School and Departments care about their students and help them succeed. Has a good culture for graduate students. Management seems to care for students' work/life balance.
cons: Still on the smaller side, so there are not as many options as there would be at larger schools, but this is getting better.

review_title: I worked here for 2 years and it was the best work environment
pros:
Flexible schedules 
Positive environment  
Great training 
Learned a lot about how to deal with rejection 
Learned how to better talk to people over the phone
cons: None, a perfect part time job for someone who is in college

review_title: Great campus environment but can suffer from department politics
pros: University environment is vibrant, No two days are alike, exceptional benefits
cons: Department politics can cause poor morale, poor pay compared to private sector

review_title: Resources prioritized in this order: football program; STEM;  and College of Business.
job_title: Assistant Professor, Sociology in Boise, ID
pros: Sports campus that relies heavily on out of state tuition.
cons: Sorely lacks diversity from US-based population groups. Humanities and social sciences are leveraged for their FTEs.

job_title: Student Services Coordinator in Meridian, ID
pros: I love the culture of working at a University. Boise State is very inclusive and friendly.
cons: Boise State is a "state" agency and we are held to decisions made by the State Board of Education and that can get muddy.

pros: Such a great, warm, inclusive environment. I learned so much through my work as a peer educator.
cons: Sometimes the prostaff can be passive aggressive in the way they give feedback.

review_title: Good, but with an ability to be much better.
pros: The university on a whole is on an upswing.
cons: Sometimes (but not all the time) there seems to be focus on the bottom dollar over student development. This is usually coming from top level management instead of the middle level.

pros: Outstanding learning opportunity! Of course everything depends on what lab/PI you work for, but BSU is unique in that undergraduates play a very important hands-on role in research.
cons: Can be demanding keeping up with a full time academic schedule while performing research related activities.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boise, ID
pros: Excellent team work, environment to build technical skills through strong communication skills, great school where one can experience industrial environment while working in the lab.
cons: Number of industries are less than comparing other states so any individual would find problem seeking for jobs with qualifications.

pros: It works around my schedule as a student. Great supervisors, and very very supportive faculty.
cons: It might get stressful if you cannot have a work-school balance. But if you can handle your studies along with it. It's GREAT!

pros: Great boss (Marissa Schmidt), great coworkers, and decent pay/hours scheduling.
cons: One rotten apple employee, and no one cleans the labs!!!

job_title: Occupational Safety & Health Consultant in Boise, ID
pros: Great benefits. Awesome town. HR is excellent.
cons: Depending on department there is not room for advancement. Specific managers are not open to new ways of doing things and are gender biased. Raises are based on 1 persons opinion.

pros: The administration has a forward looking vision. A fun, collaborative work environment. I worked in a low end position but still felt like I was part of something larger.
cons: Relatively low pay and few benefits for those working in my division.

review_title: Really great, I love working in higer ed.
job_title: Assistant Research Coordinator in Boise, ID
pros: It's a really great place to work. I love working with faculty and students, and higher education is pretty awesome.
cons: It can sometimes get exhausting working in an environment is seasonal changes in work-load and focus.

review_title: Boise State is an awesome place to work. Wonderful benefits and great coworders
job_title: Student Success and Satisfaction in Boise, ID
pros: Love the campus, students are great, and an overall positive environmnet
cons: can't think of any at this time.

pros: Wonderful employees. Organized. Fun. Everyone balanced their lives well with work and everyone was respectful. Great pay.
cons: Work can be dull because not many people come into the office, however, this could also be a pro depending on your mood.

pros: Access to campus resources, like food, rec-center, events ect... are great. Great benefits and vacation time.
cons: No discounted parking on campus (in fact it's more expensive for employees than students). Your experience will vary depending on your manager or department.

pros: Very friendly and supportive people, the  opportunity to work and study in BSU, good discount for tuitions,  benefits for part-time workers (Health insurance, PERSI, paid vacation hours)
cons: Salaries are not very attractive

review_title: Working in the Student Union Building
pros: Big production opportunities for learning designers.
cons: Limited creative, working in scope of BSU brand.

pros: Very Safe Environment,  Everyone around the campus is very friendly and will seldom find someone not friendly
cons: Does not use all the resources available, Sometimes it can be too much of a small town because everyone knows each other

pros:
-great experience using social media sites
-learned a lot about SEO and how a magazine/newspaper production works
cons:
-office environment poor 
-employees talked badly about each other constantly

pros: Tuition was only $5/credit hour
cons:
Pay is soooo very low for the cost of living in the Treasure Valley.  
Manager didn't really manage or participate.

pros:
Community atmosphere.
Kind, generous, laid-back and down to earth environment
GREAT benefits
cons:
Pay isn't great - but benefits make up for it
Can be political sometimes - who you know can be of more interest than what you can do

pros:
Flexible schedules
Good pay-scale
Career center helps the students to find a job
cons: Work is difficult sometimes it gets boring. But this is usual as a student worker

job_title: Graduate Assistant for Department of Management in Boise, ID
pros: Flexible hours, waived my tuition while working as a GA, nice new business building
cons: finding hours by working with professors can be hard. Make sure you network and build connections to get a consistent workflow

pros: Great culture of innovation and openness to new ideas. Boise is an incredible community
cons: The salaries are low compared to peers and the level of investment by the State of Idaho continues to diminish.

pros: Staff teams are exceptional, always here to give a hand if needed. They do all their best to make you feel like home.
